Introduction

Piḷḷai-lokācārya [1264-1369 CE]

After the death of Srī Rāmānuja, Parāśara Bhaṭṭa (Born 1074 AD) continued the work of propagating Viśiṣṭādvaita philosophy, and he was succeeded in turn by Nañjiyar. Nañjiyar’s foremost disciple was Nam-piḷḷai (Kali-vairi-dāsa) who was gifted with such deep erudition and expository skills, that he was given the title of ‘Lokācārya’. Nam-piḷḷai who was resident in Srīraṅgam had a very studious disciple by the name of Srī Kṛṣṇa-pāda who did not wish to get married, but his mother foiled his plans to remain a bachelor by arranging his marriage at a very early age to a girl named Sri-raṅga-nācchiyār. He was studying under Nam-piḷḷai and was engaged in documenting all the teachings.
